module.name: LazFileUtils
module.short: Contains procedures and functions used for file and directory operations

descr.p: LazFileUtils contains procedures and functions used for file and directory operations. This file is part of the LazUtils package.
descr.remark: All functions are thread safe unless explicitly stated.

element.name: CompareFilenames
element.short: Gets the relative sort order for the specified file names

descr.p: CompareFilenames is an overloaded Integer function used to compare the specified file names to get their relative order in sorting operations. CompareFilenames provides implementations which accept String or PChar values (and their lengths) as arguments. The implementations are platform- and/or OS-specific; they consider whether the file system is case sensitive or when UTF-8 encoding is supported.
The return value indicates the relative order in a sort operation, and can contain the following values:

dl.dd: Filename1 comes before Filename2
Filename1 and Filename2 to have the same value
Filename1 comes after Filename2

element.name: CompareFilenames.Result
element.short: Relative sort order for the specified file names

element.name: CompareFilenames.Filename1
element.short: First file name for the comparison

element.name: CompareFilenames.Filename2
element.short: Second file name for the comparison

element.name: CompareFilenamesIgnoreCase
element.short: Gets the relative sort order for case-insensitive file names

descr.p: CompareFilenamesIgnoreCase is an overloaded Integer function used to compare the specified file names to get their relative order in case-insensitive sorting operations. CompareFilenamesIgnoreCase provides alternate implementations which accept String or PChar values (and their lengths) as arguments. The implementations are platform- and/or OS-specific; they consider whether the file system is case sensitive or when UTF-8 encoding is supported.
The return value indicates the relative order in a case-insensitive sort operation, and can contain the following values:

dl.dd: Filename1 comes before Filename2
Filename1 and Filename2 to have the same value
Filename1 comes after Filename2

element.name: CompareFilenamesIgnoreCase.Result
element.short: Relative sort order for the file names

element.name: CompareFilenamesIgnoreCase.Filename1
element.short: First file name for the comparison

element.name: CompareFilenamesIgnoreCase.Filename2
element.short: Second file name for the comparison

element.name: CompareFileExt
element.short: Performs a sort order comparison for the specified file name and extension

descr.p: CompareFileExt is an Integer function used to compare the file extension in Filename to the value in Ext. Ext may contain the '.' character, but it is not required and will be removed for the comparison. CaseSensitive indicates whether case is ignored in the comparison. When CaseSensitive contains True, CompareStr is called to perform the comparison. Otherwise, UTF8CompareText is called to compare the values. The return value will contain one of the following:

dl.dd: Filename value has a lower sort order value than Ext
Filename and Ext have the same sort order values
Filename value has a higher sort order value than Ext

descr.p: The return is 1 if Filename does not contain a file extension.

element.name: CompareFileExt.Result
element.short: Relative sort order for the compared values

element.name: CompareFileExt.Filename
element.short: File name for the comparison

element.name: CompareFileExt.Ext
element.short: File extension for the comparison

element.name: CompareFileExt.CaseSensitive
element.short: True if case sensitive comparison is needed

element.name: CompareFilenameStarts
element.short: Compares file names using the number characters in common

descr.p: CompareFilenameStarts is an Integer function used to compare the specified file names to determine their relative sort order. Arguments in Filename1 and Filename2 do not need to be the same length. When they have different lengths, the number of characters common to both are used in the comparison. CompareFilenameStarts calls CompareFileNames to perform the comparison, and get the return value for the function.
See CompareFilename for more information about the numeric return value and its meaning.

element.name: CompareFilenameStarts.Result
element.short: Relative sort order for the compared values

element.name: CompareFilenameStarts.Filename1
element.short: First file name for the comparison

element.name: CompareFilenameStarts.Filename2
element.short: Second file name for the comparison

element.name: CompareFilenames.Len1
element.short: Length of the first file name

element.name: CompareFilenames.Len2
element.short: Length of the seconds file name

element.name: DirPathExists
element.short: Indicates if the specified directory name exists in the file system

descr.p: DirPathExists is a Boolean function which indicates if the specified directory name exists in the file system. DirectoryName can contain a trailing path delimiter, but it is removed in the function. DirPathExists calls DirectoryExistsUTF8 to get the return value.

element.name: DirPathExists.Result
element.short: True when the specified directory exists in the file system

element.name: DirPathExists.DirectoryName
element.short: Directory Name to locate

element.name: DirectoryIsWritable
element.short: Indicates if the specified directory name is writable

descr.p: DirectoryIsWritable is a Boolean function used to determine if the specified directory name is writable in the file system. The path name in DirectoryName must already exist on the local file system. The return value is False if a directory with the specified name does not exist.

The return value is True when a file can be added, deleted, or modified in the specified path. To get the return value, DirectoryIsWritable creates a temporary file in DirectoryName, adds content to it, and deletes the temporary file. DirectoryIsWritable calls the FileCreateUTF8, FileWrite, FileClose, and DeleteFileUTF8 routines to perform the file operations. The return value is True when FileWrite completes successfully.
descr.remark: Please note: DirectoryIsWritable calls InvalidateFileStateCache with the temporary file name if DeleteFileUTF8 cannot remove the file.

element.name: DirectoryIsWritable.Result
element.short: True if the specified directory is writable

element.name: DirectoryIsWritable.DirectoryName
element.short: Directory name to examine in the function

element.name: ExtractFileNameOnly
element.short: Gets the base file name (without the file extension) in the specified path

descr.p: ExtractFileNameOnly is a String function used to extract the base file name (without the file extension) from the value in AFilename. Path information, up to the last directory separator ('/' or '\') or device separator (':') character, in AFileName is ignored. The file extension, starting at the '.' character, is also omitted.

element.name: ExtractFileNameOnly.Result
element.short: Base file name in the file path

element.name: ExtractFileNameOnly.AFilename
element.short: File path and name to examine in the function

element.name: FilenameIsAbsolute
element.short: Determines if the specified value is an absolute file path (not a relative one)

descr.p: FilenameIsAbsolute is a Boolean function used to determine if the value in TheFilename contains an absolute file path (and not a relative one). The implementation for FilenameIsAbsolute is platform- and/or OS-specific.

In UNIX-like environments, the FilenameIsUnixAbsolute function is used in the implementation. The return value is False if TheFilename is an empty string (''), or does not start with the directory separator for the environment.
On Windows, the FilenameIsWinAbsolute function is called in the implementation. FilenameIsWinAbsolute takes Device identifiers into consideration when examining the value in TheFilename. For example:
The return value is False if TheFilename (without the optional device identifier) is an empty string (''), or does not start with the directory separator for the environment.

element.name: FilenameIsAbsolute.Result
element.short: True when the file name is not a relative path

element.name: FilenameIsAbsolute.TheFilename
element.short: Path and file name to use in the function

element.name: FilenameIsWinAbsolute
element.short: Determines if the specified value is an absolute file path (not a relative one)

descr.p: FilenameIsWinAbsolute is a Boolean function used to determine if the value in TheFilename contains an absolute file path (and not a relative one).

On Windows, the FilenameIsWinAbsolute function is called in the implementation of FilenameIsAbsolute. FilenameIsWinAbsolute takes Device identifiers into consideration when examine the value in TheFilename. For example:
The return value is False if TheFilename (without the optional device identifier)is an empty string (''), or does not start with the directory separator for the environment.

element.name: FilenameIsWinAbsolute.Result
element.short: True when the file name is not a relative path

element.name: FilenameIsWinAbsolute.TheFilename
element.short: Path and file name to use in the function

element.name: FilenameIsUnixAbsolute
element.short: Determines if the specified value is an absolute file path (not a relative one)

descr.p: FilenameIsUnixAbsolute is a Boolean function used to determine if the value in TheFilename contains an absolute file path (and not a relative one).

In UNIX-like environments, the FilenameIsUnixAbsolute function is used in the implementation of FilenameIsAbsolute. The return value is False if TheFilename is an empty string (''), or does not start with the directory separator for the environment.

element.name: FilenameIsUnixAbsolute.Result
element.short: True when the file name is not a relative path

element.name: FilenameIsUnixAbsolute.TheFilename
element.short: Path and file name to use in the function

element.name: ForceDirectory
element.short: Creates the specified directory if it does not already exist

descr.p: ForceDirectory is a Boolean function which creates the specified directory if it does not already exist. ForceDirectory ensures that a trailing path delimiter exists in DirectoryName prior to checking the file system. Each directory in the specified path is examined in the function using DirPathExists. ForceDirectory calls CreateDirUTF8 if a directory does not exist, and may exit with a return value of False if directory creation is not successful.
The return value is True if all directories in the path information already exist, or are successfully created in the function.

element.name: ForceDirectory.Result
element.short: Returns True if directory exists or if it was successfully created

element.name: ForceDirectory.DirectoryName
element.short: Path information for the operation

element.name: CheckIfFileIsExecutable
element.short: Examines the specified file to see if it is executable

descr.p: CheckIfFileIsExecutable is a procedure used to examine the specified file name to see if it is executable. CheckIfFileIsExecutable is implemented for UNIX-like environments, and allows TProcess to better determine if the file can be executed on the platform or OS, and to get better error messages when it cannot.
CheckIfFileIsExecutable raises an exception with a specific message when the platform or OS facilities indicate it is necessary.
Use FileIsExecutable to determine of a file is executable without raising an exception.

errors.p: The Exception contains the following messages (from string resources):

dl.dd: Raised when FileExistsUTF8 returns False
Raised when DirPathExists indicates the file is actually a directory name
Raised when fpGetErrno() returns ESysEAcces
Raised when fpGetErrno() returns ESysENoEnt
Raised when fpGetErrno() returns ESysENotDir
Raised when fpGetErrno() returns ESysENoMem
Raised when fpGetErrno() returns ESysELoop
Raised when fpGetErrno() has a value other than the above

element.name: CheckIfFileIsExecutable.AFilename
element.short: File name to examine

element.name: FileIsExecutable
element.short: Determines if the specified file name is executable

descr.p: FileIsExecutable is a Boolean function used to determine if the specified file name is executable. For UNIX-like environments, a combination of FpStat, FPS_ISREG, and FpAccess are used to get the return value. For the Windows environment, the value from FileExistsUTF8 is used as the return value. In short, the function is not really useful in a Windows environment.

element.name: FileIsExecutable.Result
element.short: True if the file is executable on the platform or OS

element.name: FileIsExecutable.AFilename
element.short: File name to examine

element.name: FileIsReadable
element.short: Indicates if the specified file name is readable

descr.p: FileIsReadable is a Boolean function which indicates if the specified file name is readable. For UNIX-like environments, FpAccess is used to get the return value. On Windows, the return value is the result from FileExistsUTF8. In short, the function is not really useful on the Windows platform.

element.name: FileIsReadable.Result
element.short: True when the specified file name is readable

element.name: FileIsReadable.AFilename
element.short: File name to examine

element.name: FileIsWritable
element.short: Indicates if the specified file name is writable

descr.p: FileIsWritable is a Boolean function which indicates if the specified file name is writable. For UNIX-like environments, FpAccess is used to get the return value. For Windows, FileGetAttrUTF8 is used to determine if faReadOnly is omitted from the attributes for the file.

element.name: FileIsWritable.Result
element.short: True when the specified file name is writable

element.name: FileIsWritable.AFilename
element.short: File name to examine

element.name: FileIsText
element.short: Determines if the specified file contains plain text content

descr.p: FileIsText is a Boolean function used to determine if the specified file contains plain text content. The overloaded variant that includes the FileReadable argument is used to examine the content in the file.
FileIsText calls FileOpenUtf8 for the specified file name. The return value is False is the file handle contains feInvalidHandle.
FileIsText checks for (and skips) common Byte Order Marks, such as:

Content in the file (up to 1024 characters) is checked to ensure that invalid Null and Control characters are not found in the file. The return value is True when the specified file name exists in the local file system, and does not contain Null or Control characters.

element.name: FileIsText.Result
element.short: True when the file contains plain text content

element.name: FileIsText.AFilename
element.short: File name to examine in the function

element.name: FileIsText.FileReadable
element.short: Indicates if the specified file was successfully opened and read

descr.p: FilenameIsTrimmed is an overloaded Boolean function used to determine if the specified file name contains characters to remove or resolve before use. The variant which uses PChar values performs the comparison. The return value is False when the file name is a candidate for use of TrimFilename to remove whitespace or special characters.
Use TrimFilename to remove leading or trailing whitespace, duplicate directory separators, or relative path symbols.

element.name: FilenameIsTrimmed.Result
element.short: False when the file name needs to trimmed

element.name: FilenameIsTrimmed.TheFilename
element.short: File name to examine in the function

element.name: FilenameIsTrimmed.StartPos
element.short: PChar with the file name value

element.name: FilenameIsTrimmed.NameLen
element.short: Length of the file name

element.name: TrimFilename
element.short: Removes leading and trailing spaces, and resolves special characters
element.descr: TrimFilename is a String function used to remove leading and trailing spaces (Decimal 32) in the specified path and file name. In addition, ResolveDots is called to expand directory characters (like '.' and '..') and to remove duplicate path delimiters (like '//').

element.name: TrimFilename.Result
element.short: New value for the path and file name

element.name: TrimFilename.AFilename
element.short: Path and file name for the operation

element.name: CleanAndExpandFilename
element.short: Removes whitespace and resolves special characters in the specified file name

descr.p: CleanAndExpandFilename is a String function used to remove whitespace and to resolve special characters in the specified file name. CleanAndExpandFilename calls TrimFilename and ExpandFileNameUTF8 to get the return value for the function. The return value is the current directory when Filename contains an empty string ('').

element.name: CleanAndExpandFilename.Result
element.short: File name with whitespace removed and special characters resolved

element.name: CleanAndExpandFilename.Filename
element.short: File name to examine in the function

element.name: CleanAndExpandDirectory
element.short: Removes whitespace and resolves special characters in the specified path

descr.p: CleanAndExpandDirectory is a String function used to remove whitespace and resolve special characters in the specified path. CleanAndExpandDirectory calls CleanAndExpandFilename to get the return value for the function. CleanAndExpandDirectory calls AppendPathDelim to ensure that a trailing path delimiter is included in the return value. The return value is the current directory when the specified path contains an empty string ('').

element.name: CleanAndExpandDirectory.Result
element.short: Path information after removing whitespace and resolving special characters

element.name: CleanAndExpandDirectory.Filename
element.short: Path information for the function

element.name: TrimAndExpandFilename
element.short: Cleans and resolves a file path to the specified base directory name

descr.p: TrimAndExpandFilename is a String function used to remove whitespace and special characters in Filename, and to resolve the relative file path to the directory in BaseDir. TrimAndExpandFilename removes a trailing path delimiter in Filename, and calls ExpandFileNameUTF8 and TrimFilename to get the return value for the function.
The return value is an empty string ('') if Filename contains an empty string ('').

element.name: TrimAndExpandFilename.Result
element.short: Cleaned and resolved file path

element.name: TrimAndExpandFilename.Filename
element.short: File name for the function

element.name: TrimAndExpandFilename.BaseDir
element.short: Base directory name used for a relative file path

element.name: TrimAndExpandDirectory
element.short: Cleans and resolves a relative path to a base directory

descr.p: TrimAndExpandDirectory is a String function used to remove whitespace and special characters in the path information, and to resolve a relative path to the specified base directory.
TrimAndExpandDirectory calls TrimFilename. The return value is an empty string ('') when TrimFilename returns an empty string ('').
TrimAndExpandDirectory calls ExpandFileNameUTF8 to resolve the relative path, and calls TrimFilename to get the return value for the function.

element.name: TrimAndExpandDirectory.Result
element.short: Path information cleaned and resolved to the specified base directory

element.name: TrimAndExpandDirectory.Filename
element.short: Path information for the function

element.name: TrimAndExpandDirectory.BaseDir
element.short: Base directory used to resolve a relative path

element.name: CreateRelativePath
element.short: Creates a relative path from BaseDirectory to Filename

descr.p: CreateRelativePath is a String function used to get the relative path from BaseDirectory to Filename. A trailing path delimiter in BaseDirectory is ignored. If there is no relative path, the value in Filename is returned.

When BaseDirectory and Filename contain the same value, and UsePointDirectory is False, an empty string ('') is used as the return value. If UsePointDirectory contains True, the return value is '.'. Duplicate path delimiters are removed. For example, the following is True:
descr.remark: CreateRelativePath is thread safe and therefore does not guarantee that the current directory is correct for file names like 'D:test.txt'.

element.name: CreateRelativePath.Result
element.short: Relative path from the base directory for the file name

element.name: CreateRelativePath.Filename
element.short: File name for the operation

element.name: CreateRelativePath.BaseDirectory
element.short: Base directory for the relative path

element.name: CreateRelativePath.UsePointDirectory
element.short: True if '.' (current directory symbol) is prepended to the relative path

element.name: FileIsInPath
element.short: Returns True if Filename exists in the specified Path

descr.p: FileIsInPath is a Boolean function which indicates if the file name exists in the specified path. Filename is the file name to locate, and may include optional relative path information. For example: '../filename.txt'.
Path is the directory name used to locate the specified file. For example: '/usr/lib/fpc'.

The returns value is True when Filename is a file or directory somewhere below Path. For example, under UNIX the Filename '/usr/lib/fpc' is below Path '/usr/lib', '/usr' and '/'. When Filename and Path contain the same value, the return value is False. Please note: the return value is False when Path contains an empty string ('').

FileIsInPath calls ResolveDots to resolve relative path information in both Filename and Path, and ensures that a trailing path delimiter is included in Path when needed. FileIsInPath calls CompareFileNames.
descr.remark: This is a logical test; FileIsInPath does not expand or follow symbolic links.

element.name: FileIsInPath.Result
element.short: True when the file exists in the specified path

element.name: FileIsInPath.Filename
element.short: File name to locate

element.name: FileIsInPath.Path
element.short: Path used for the operation

element.name: AppendPathDelim
element.short: Adds a trailing path delimiter when needed

descr.p: AppendPathDelim is a String function used to ensure that a trailing path delimiter is included in the specified Path. The return value includes the value in Path and the trailing path delimiter (when needed).

element.name: AppendPathDelim.Result
element.short: Path value with a trailing path delimiter

element.name: AppendPathDelim.Path
element.short: Path value to examine

element.name: ChompPathDelim
element.short: Removes a trailing path delimiter from the specified value

descr.p: ChompPathDelim is a String function used to remove a trailing path delimiter from the specified value in Path. For environments where UNC paths are allowed, ChompPathDelim ensures that the UNC path delimiters are retained. Windows Device identifiers, such as "D:" are also retained in Path.

element.name: ChompPathDelim.Result
element.short: Path information after removing the trailing path delimiter

element.name: ChompPathDelim.Path
element.short: Path information for the function

element.name: FileExistsUTF8
element.short: Indicates if the specified file name exists

descr.p: FileExistsUTF8 is a Boolean function which indicates if the specified file name exists in the local file system. For the Windows environment, FileExistsUTF8 uses FileGetAttrUTF8 to ensure that Filename does not have the FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DIRECTORY attribute. For UNIX-like environments, the FileExists function in SysUtils is used to get the return value.

element.name: FileExistsUTF8.Result
element.short: True when the specified file name exists

element.name: FileExistsUTF8.Filename
element.short: File name to locate in the file system

element.name: FileAgeUTF8
element.short: Returns the last modification time for the file in FileDate format

descr.p: FileAgeUTF8 is a Longint function which returns the last modification time for the file in FileName. FileAgeUTF8 cannot be used on directories, and returns -1 if FileName indicates a directory.

For UNIX-like environments, the return value is provided by the FileAge function in SysUtils. For the Windows environment, FindFirstFileW is used to get TWin32FindDataW data for the specified file. Its ftLastWriteTime value is converted using WinToDosTime to get the return value for the function.
The return value is in FileDate format, and can be transformed to TDateTime format with the FileDateToDateTime function.

element.name: FileAgeUTF8.Result
element.short: Last modification time for the file in FileDate format

element.name: FileAgeUTF8.FileName
element.short: File name for the function

element.name: DirectoryExistsUTF8
element.short: Determine if the specified path exists on the local file system

descr.p: DirectoryExistsUTF8 is Boolean function used to determine if the specified path exists on the local file system. For the Windows environment, FileGetAttrUTF8 is called to see if FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DIRECTORY is include in the file attributes for Directory. For UNIX-like environments, the DirectoryExists function in SysUtils is used to get the return value.

element.name: DirectoryExistsUTF8.Result
element.short: True when the directory exists in the file system

element.name: DirectoryExistsUTF8.Directory
element.short: Directory name to locate in the file system

element.name: ExpandFileNameUTF8
element.short: Expands the values in FileName and BaseDir to an absolute file name

descr.p: ExpandFileNameUTF8 is a String function which expands the UTF-8-encoded values in FileName and BaseDir to an absolute file name. It changes all directory separator characters to the one appropriate for the system.

If an empty string ('') is passed in Filename, it is expanded to the current directory using GetCurrentDirUTF8. When FileName contains the tilde character ('~'), it is converted to the path to the home directory for the user using the HOME environment variable. Relative paths in FileName are resolved by calling ResolveDots.

element.name: ExpandFileNameUTF8.Result
element.short: File name with an absolute path

element.name: ExpandFileNameUTF8.FileName
element.short: File name for the operation

element.name: ExpandFileNameUTF8.BaseDir
element.short: Base directory for the operation

element.name: FindFirstUTF8
element.short: Starts searching for files matching the specified path value

descr.p: FindFirstUTF8 searches the file specified in Path. Normal files, as well as all special files which have the attributes specified in Attr will be returned.

It returns a SearchRec record for further searching in Rslt. Path can contain wildcard characters; ? (matches any single character) and * (matches 0 or more arbitrary characters). In this case FindFirstUTF8 will return the first file which matches the specified criteria.
The return value contains the result from GetLastError; a non-zero value indicates that no files matching the criteria were found.

element.name: FindFirstUTF8.Result
element.short: Last error number encountered in the function

element.name: FindFirstUTF8.Path
element.short: Path and/or file name to locate

element.name: FindFirstUTF8.Attr
element.short: File attributes to include in the search

element.name: FindFirstUTF8.Rslt
element.short: Search record for the first matching file

element.name: FindNextUTF8
element.short: Locates another file matching the search criteria

descr.p: FindNextUTF8 is a Longint function used to locate another file matching the TSearchRec value in Rslt. Rslt is populated in a prior call to FindFirstUTF8, and updated in FindNextUTF8.
For the Windows environment, FindNextFileW is called to compare the TWIN32FINDDATAW for the matching file. For UNIX-like environments, the FindNext function in SysUtils is used.
The return value contains the result from GetLastError; a non-zero value indicates that an error was encountered.

element.name: FindNextUTF8.Result
element.short: Last error number

element.name: FindNextUTF8.Rslt
element.short: Search criteria for the function

element.name: FindCloseUTF8
element.short: Frees resources allocated to the specified search record

descr.p: FindCloseUTF8 is a procedure used to free resources allocated to the search record in F in FindFirstUTF8. FindCloseUTF8 calls the FindClose function in SysUtils.

element.name: FindCloseUTF8.F
element.short: Search record to free in the procedure

element.name: FileSetDateUTF8
element.short: Sets the last modification time for the file

descr.p: FileSetDateUTF8 is a Longint function used to set the last modification time for the file to the specified Age in FileDate format. Use DateTimeToFileDate to convert a TDateTime value to FileDate format.

For the Windows environment, a handle is created for the specified file name, and SetFileTime is called to store the updated file age. For UNIX-like environments, FileSetDate in SysUtils is called to set the file age. InvalidateFileStateCache is also called for the specified file name.
The return value is the value from GetLastError; a non-zero value indicates that an error has occurred.

element.name: FileSetDateUTF8.Result
element.short: Last error number in the function

element.name: FileSetDateUTF8.FileName
element.short: File name to update in the function

element.name: FileSetDateUTF8.Age
element.short: New value for the last modification time

element.name: FileGetAttrUTF8
element.short: Gets the value of file attributes for the specified file name

descr.p: FileGetAttrUTF8 is a Longint function used to get files attributes for the specified file name. For the Windows environment, GetFileAttributesW in Windows is called to the file attribute value for Filename. For UNIX-like environments, FileGetAttr in SysUtils is called to the the return value.
The return value contains a numeric value that can be OR-ed with the following constants to get a specific file attribute:

dl.dd: The file is read-only
The file is hidden (On UNIX, the filename starts with a dot)
The file is a system file (On UNIX, the file is a character, block or FIFO file).
Volume Label (For DOS/Windows on a plain FAT - not VFAT or Fat32)
File is a directory
File is ready to be archived (Not possible on UNIX)

element.name: FileGetAttrUTF8.Result
element.short: File attribute value for the specified file name

element.name: FileGetAttrUTF8.FileName
element.short: File name for the function

element.name: FileSetAttrUTF8
element.short: Sets the file attribute value for the specified file name

descr.p: FileSetAttrUTF8 is a Longint function used to set the file attributes for the specified file name to the value in Attr. The value in Attr can be set by AND-ing predefined file attribute constants, such as:

dl.dd: The file is read-only
The file is hidden (On UNIX, the filename starts with a dot)
The file is a system file (On UNIX, the file is a character, block or FIFO file).
Volume Label (For DOS/Windows on a plain FAT - not VFAT or Fat32)
File is a directory
File is ready to be archived (Not possible on UNIX)

descr.p: For UNIX-like environments, FileSetAttr in SysUtils is called to set the file attributes value. InvalidateFileStateCache is also called for the specified file name. For the Windows environment, SetFileAttributesW in Windows is called to set the attributes value for the specified file name.
The return value contains the result from GetLastError; a non-zero value indicates that an error has occurred.

element.name: FileSetAttrUTF8.Result
element.short: Last error number from the function

element.name: FileSetAttrUTF8.Filename
element.short: File name to update in the function

element.name: FileSetAttrUTF8.Attr
element.short: File attribute value for the specified file name

element.name: DeleteFileUTF8
element.short: Deletes the specified file name

descr.p: DeleteFileUTF8 is a Boolean function used to delete the specified file name.

For the Windows environment, DeleteFileW in Windows is called to remove the specified file name. For UNIX-like environments, DeleteFile in SysUtils is called to delete the specified file name. InvalidateFileStateCache is also called.
The return value contains True when Filename is successfully deleted from the local file system.

element.name: DeleteFileUTF8.Result
element.short: True if the specified file name is deleted

element.name: DeleteFileUTF8.FileName
element.short: File name to delete in the function

element.name: RenameFileUTF8
element.short: Renames a file to the specified value

descr.p: RenameFileUTF8 is a Boolean function used to rename a file to the specified new value.

For the Windows environment, MoveFileW is called to rename the file using the values specified in OldName and NewName. For UNIX-like environments, RenameFile in SysUtils is called to rename the file to the specified new value. InvalidateFileStateCache is also called.
The return value is True if the file is renamed successfully.

element.name: RenameFileUTF8.Result
element.short: True if the file is successfully renamed to the new value

element.name: RenameFileUTF8.OldName
element.short: Existing name for the file

element.name: RenameFileUTF8.NewName
element.short: New name for the file

element.name: FileSearchUTF8
element.short: Searches for a file with the specified name in the list of directory paths

descr.p: FileSearchUTF8 is a String function used to search for files with the specified name in the list of directory paths.

DirList is a list of file paths to search in the function. Values in DirList are separated by the PathSeparator character for the environment. No additional directories are searched when DirList contains an empty string ('').

ImplicitCurrentDir controls whether the search is implicitly limited to the current directory. The default value for ImplicitCurrentDir is True. When a file with the specified Name is located in the current directory, no additional searches are needed. The return value is the name of the file without any path information.

When ImplicitCurrentDir is False, each path in DirList is searched for a file with the specified name. The search is stopped when the first file with the specified file name is found. The return value contains the path in DirList where the file name was located along with the file name, or an empty string ('') if the specified file is not found.

element.name: FileSearchUTF8.Result
element.short: Path and file name for the matching file, or an empty string

element.name: FileSearchUTF8.Name
element.short: File name to locate in the list of directory paths

element.name: FileSearchUTF8.DirList
element.short: The delimited list of directory paths to search

element.name: FileIsReadOnlyUTF8
element.short: Determines if the specified file is marked as read-only

descr.p: FileIsReadOnlyUTF8 is a Boolean function used to determine if the specified file is marked as read-only in the local file system. FileIsReadOnlyUTF8 calls FileGetAttrUTF8 for the specified file name and checks to see if faReadOnly has been included in the file attributes value. The return value is True when faReadOnly has been included in the file attributes.

element.name: FileIsReadOnlyUTF8.Result
element.short: True when the file is marked as read-only

element.name: FileIsReadOnlyUTF8.FileName
element.short: File name to examine in the function

element.name: GetCurrentDirUTF8
element.short: Gets the name for the current directory
element.descr:
GetCurrentDirUTF8 is a String function used to get the name for the current directory in the local file system.
For the Windows environment, GetCurrentDirectoryW is called to get the current directory name. UTF8Encode is called to convert the WideString value to UTF-8, and used as the return value for the function.
For UNIX-like environments, GetCurrentDir in SysUtils is called to get the current directory name.

element.name: GetCurrentDirUTF8.Result
element.short: Name for the current directory

element.name: SetCurrentDirUTF8
element.short: Sets the current directory to the specified name

descr.p: SetCurrentDirUTF8 is a Boolean function used to set the current directory in the local file system to the specified value.

For the Windows environment, UTFDecode is called to convert NewDir and passed to SetCurrentDirectoryW to set the current directory name. Windows CE raises an exception in SetCurrentDirUtf8; the concept of a current directory does not exist in Windows CE.
For UNIX-like environments, SetCurrentDir in SysUtils is used to set the current directory to the specified value.
The return value is True if the current directory is successfully changed to the new value.

dl.dd: Raised for the Windows CE environment; exception message is: '[SetCurrentDirWide] The concept of the current directory doesn't exist in Windows CE'

element.name: SetCurrentDirUTF8.Result
element.short: True if the current directory was successfully changed to the new value

element.name: SetCurrentDirUTF8.NewDir
element.short: Directory name to use as the current directory

element.name: CreateDirUTF8
element.short: Creates a new directory with the specified name

descr.p: CreateDirUTF8 is a Boolean function used to create a new directory in the local file system with the specified name. For the Windows environments, the value in NewDir is converted to wide string format and passed to the CreateDirectoryW function in the Windows unit. For UNIX-like environments, CreateDir in SysUtils is used to create the new directory with the specified name.
The return value is True if the new directory is successfully created.

errors.p: An error can occur if a directory with the specified name already exists in the local file system.

element.name: CreateDirUTF8.Result
element.short: True if the new directory is successfully created

element.name: CreateDirUTF8.NewDir
element.short: Name for the new directory

element.name: RemoveDirUTF8
element.short: Removes the directory with the specified name

descr.p: RemoveDirUTF8 is a Boolean function used to remove the directory with the specified name from the local file system.
For the Windows environment, UTF8Decode is called to convert the value in Dir to wide string format. The RemoveDirectoryW function in the Windows unit is called to remove the specified directory.
For UNIX-like environments, RemoveDir in SysUtils is called to remove the specified directory.
The return value is True when the specified directory is successfully removed.

element.name: RemoveDirUTF8.Result
element.short: True when the directory is successfully removed

element.name: RemoveDirUTF8.Dir
element.short: Name of the directory to remove in the function

element.name: ForceDirectoriesUTF8
element.short: Creates the specified directories if they do not already exist

descr.p: ForceDirectories is a Boolean function which creates the specified directories if they do not already exist. ForceDirectories examines the value in Dir to determine if it contains a Windows device identifier or a UNC name. If a device identifier or UNC name is found, but not supported on the platform, no actions are performed in the function.
ForceDirectories raises an EInOutError exception with the message in SCannotCreateEmptyDir when Dir contains an empty string ('').

Each directory in the specified path is checked using DirectoryExistsUTF8. ForceDirectories calls CreateDirUTF8 if a directory does not already exist, and may exit with a return value of False if directory creation is not successful. The return value is True if all directories in the path information already exist, or are successfully created in the function.

dl.dd: Raised when the directory name is an empty string (''); Message is SCannotCreateEmptyDir, and ErrorCode is set to 3.

element.name: ForceDirectoriesUTF8.Result
element.short: True when directories exist or are successfully created in the function

element.name: ForceDirectoriesUTF8.Dir
element.short: Path information to examine the function

element.name: TInvalidateFileStateCacheEvent
element.short: Specifies the event signalled for an invalid file state in the file cache

descr.p: TInvalidateFileStateCacheEvent is a type which specifies the event signalled for an invalid file state in the file cache. TInvalidateFileStateCacheEvent is the type used for the OnInvalidateFileStateCache event handler.

element.name: TInvalidateFileStateCacheEvent.Filename
element.short: File name for the event notification

element.name: OnInvalidateFileStateCache
element.short: Implements the event handler for a file with an invalid file state

descr.p: OnInvalidateFileStateCache is a TInvalidateFileStateCacheEvent variable which implements the event handler signalled for a file with an invalid file state. OnInvalidateFileStateCache allows an application to respond to the event notification for a specific file. OnInvalidateFileStateCache is signalled when InvalidateFileStateCache is called by routines that perform file manipulation.
OnInvalidateFileStateCache is significant for UNIX-like environments only, such as Linux and Amiga. OnInvalidateFileStateCache is not used in Windows environments.

element.name: InvalidateFileStateCache
element.short: Signals the OnInvalidateFileStateCache event handler

descr.p: InvalidateFileStateCache is a procedure used to signal the OnInvalidateFileStateCache event handler for the specified file name. InvalidateFileStateCache is used when an invalid file state is detected in routines which perform file manipulation, such as:
InvalidateFileStateCache is significant for UNIX-like environments only, such as Linux and Amiga. InvalidateFileStateCache is not used in Windows environments.

element.name: SplitCmdLineParams
element.short: Splits command line parameters separated by whitespace characters

descr.p: Parameters are separated by one or more whitespace characters (#9,#10,#13,#32). Quoted values are parsed as a single parameter. If ReadBackslash contains True, then \" is replaced with " and not treated as a quoted value. #0 (Decimal 0) is always treated as the end of the Parameters value.

element.name: ReadAllLinks
element.short: Resolves a symbolic link to an actual file name

descr.p: Resolves a symbolic link to an actual file name. It does not resolve symlinks in parent directories. If a symlink can not be resolved and if ExceptionOnError is False, the function returns an empty string (''). If ExceptionOnError is True, it raises an EFOpenError with a message, containing more details. On Windows it simply returns Filename.

element.name: GetUnixPhysicalFilename
element.short: Resolves all symlinks in Filename, including all directories

descr.p: If a symlink can not be resolved, and ExceptionOnError is False, the function returns the empty string (''). If ExceptionOnError is True, it raises an EFOpenError with a message containing more details.

element.name: TryReadAllLinks
element.short: Resolves a symlink to the real file

descr.p: If a symlink can not be resolved it returns Filename. It uses ReadAllLinks.

element.name: ResolveDots
element.short: Removes duplicate path delimiters and resolves . and ..

descr.p: This function shortens duplicate path delimiters to single path delimiters. It resolves 'A/../B' to 'B', which might be wrong under Unix if A is a symlink. The functions does not check the file system. The single dot './A' is resolved to 'A', but a single '.' is retained.

element.name: SHGetFolderPathUTF8
element.short: Works like the WinAPI function SHGetFolderPathW, but returns a UTF-8-encoded string
